Posts.Content: Welcome brew, no man wants to get PC but many, including myself, who do would love to trade their numbers for your dads. It's a pretty good bet what ever he dies from as an old man will not be PC. His weight loss could be due to stress thinking about whether or not he might have pc before he was even diagnosed. As you gain more knowledge about PC from the members here I'm positive your stress level will drop dramatically. Allen
Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Hi mom, I had SLF in 2013, it was 11 months after my PSA rose to 0.17 after having DaVinci surgery. I had virtually no side effects and carried on with my life. To date the only issue I've had is a little blood in the urine if I lift something over 25 pounds.Apparently a small portion of my bladder got burned and some of the blood vessels in that area burst. So I'm careful and have no further bleeding since a Cysto showed the issue. On the upside I get to avoid some yard work. Allen

Posts.Content: Congrats Dave on a great result. I think you are way to eager to resume your normal schedule which could set you back, and might even be dangerous.Let your body heal then slowly resume your sports activities, but not before you have 6 weeks behind you. If your term "A LOT of coffee" means 3 or more then I suggest you cut it back . I wish you continued success with your recovery. Allen

Posts.Content: Obviously if your husband refuses a biopsy, then the issue is finalized. It could be given his health issues at a relatively young age that he is experiencing mild depression. Have you spoken to the doctor to get his opinion on the risk factor to your husband if surgery or radiation were necessary? Your husband should have many productive years ahead of him, it would in my opinion be a shame if he didn't get those years because he refused to stay on top of his health. If you are unable to get through to him perhaps a sibling or one of his children could. I know it must be difficult for you. Good luck Allen

Posts.Content: I started 24 hours after the catheter was removed. At that time I was lying on a table in my physiotherapists office learning the proper way to do the Kegel exercises while watching my pelvic floor on the monitor. I measured the urine leakage daily by weighing the pads. The first 10 days I went through a LOT of pull ups and pads. However, at the end of 7 weeks I was fully continent. Good luck Allen

Posts.Content: Cvmiller, assuming surgery is the way you are going there is no really BETTER type. Most, including myself opt for Robotic as it is less invasive and the healing time is quicker. It is shown not to be any more or less successful than open surgery. Open surgery has improved recovery time considerably, and you can usually get it done much sooner. The biggest decision is your choice of surgeons no matter which you go with. You want one with lots of experience. Allen

Posts.Content: Hi Brock I have 26 sessions of radiation behind me and 7 to go. So far I haven't had any side affects other than by Friday I get a bit fatigued by 9PM. By Saturday I am fine . If your procedure is like mine it will be very important that you have an empty bowel and a full bladder for each procedure. They do a mini CT scan before each treatment to ensure you are ok to go. If your bladder isn't full they will get you to drink more water and wait 30-60 min. Each treatment lasts about 12 minutes.. Hope this helps a bit. B

Posts.Title: Newcomer - Recovering three days after RALRP

Posts.Content: LIBMRDUCKS welcome to the site. I had surgery for my prostate issue, however after a year my psa started climbing so I decided upon beam radiation. I had 33 rounds of treatment. In my case I had 1 target and they hit it twice from 2 different directions. The actual radiation beam was 6 sec each direction. How many tattoos (markings) do you have on your body? My treatment was at most inconvenient as my bladder had to be full, and my bowel had to be empty for each procedure. Other than a little fatigue on the last day of treatment that lasted about 10-15 min I was perfectly fine, and could go about my life as normal. You will experience nerve damage from the radiation and that will affect you with ED. So that's a quick overview, if you have a specific question I would be more than willing to tell you how it affected me. It would appear your wife's course of action is not causing you additional stress so that is works in your favor. Allen
Posts.Title: What can I expect after 18 beam Radiation Treatments and should I get regular PSA tes

Posts.Content: Shinytop- Keep positive I wishing you good luck. B
Posts.Title: Biopsy Today

Posts.Content: My oncologist only did PSA testing 3 months after radiation, as radiation works differently from surgery obviously. A week later you could get a PSA number close to the original number but 3 months later it could be zero. As I was going away for 4 months to Florida my doctor did my PSA immediately after the treatments ended, it was down by 0.02 for a total of 0.15. Four months later it was 0.0 B

Posts.Title: Bladder Spasm?

Posts.Content: My oncologist only did PSA testing 3 months after radiation, as radiation works differently from surgery obviously. A week later you could get a PSA number close to the original number but 3 months later it could be zero. As I was going away for 4 months to Florida my doctor did my PSA immediately after the treatments ended, it was down by 0.02 for a total of 0.15. Four months later it was 0.0 B

Posts.Title: What can I expect after 18 beam Radiation Treatments and should I get regular PSA tes

Posts.Content: Hi Brock I have 26 sessions of radiation behind me and 7 to go. So far I haven't had any side affects other than by Friday I get a bit fatigued by 9PM. By Saturday I am fine . If your procedure is like mine it will be very important that you have an empty bowel and a full bladder for each procedure. They do a mini CT scan before each treatment to ensure you are ok to go. If your bladder isn't full they will get you to drink more water and wait 30-60 min. Each treatment lasts about 12 minutes.. Hope this helps a bit. B

Posts.Title: SRT completed!

Posts.Content: LIBMRDUCKS welcome to the site. I had surgery for my prostate issue, however after a year my psa started climbing so I decided upon beam radiation. I had 33 rounds of treatment. In my case I had 1 target and they hit it twice from 2 different directions. The actual radiation beam was 6 sec each direction. How many tattoos (markings) do you have on your body? My treatment was at most inconvenient as my bladder had to be full, and my bowel had to be empty for each procedure. Other than a little fatigue on the last day of treatment that lasted about 10-15 min I was perfectly fine, and could go about my life as normal. You will experience nerve damage from the radiation and that will affect you with ED. So that's a quick overview, if you have a specific question I would be more than willing to tell you how it affected me. It would appear your wife's course of action is not causing you additional stress so that is works in your favor. Allen

Posts.Content: Mark, I truly hope you don't remain in that dark place and you do prove the doctor's wrong. Obviously you have a rough road ahead of you but your best chance of proving the doctor's wrong is to stand up and keep swinging. I'm sure in the next 6 years there will be many new drugs and advancements in treatments for PC. It is the wish of all people with cancer. Keep us in the loop and know you are in my prayers. Allen

Posts.Title: 2 months out

Posts.Content: Give it a bit more time. It took me 7 weeks to become fully continent and 12 weeks to get into my pre-surgery work out routine. I never really experienced tiredness and certainly not shortness of breath, hopefully you have told your doctor about these issues. Two months is quite optimistic to expect an erection, at your age 6-9 months would be more realistic I think. If you get the green light from your doctor re your shortness of breath then tell him you plan to push yourself and do more exercise every day, even if it's only a little more. Good Luck and don't get to impatient B

Posts.Title: New Guy Here, Surgery on Monday

Posts.Content: Hello Gerd. I too live in Canada and spend 5 months/year in Florida and 2-3 weeks in Europe, I had DaVinci surgery 5 years ago and have never been asked about it. Royal Bank where I buy it have a bout 7-8 questions and cancer isn't one of them. A few weeks after surgery I developed a UTI went to a Florida hospital for blood tests and prescription. Called the bank to inform them and they said no problem. The hospital billed them directly for 2 visits ($1,600) and I paid for the prescription and mailed the bill to the bank . I had my money in 2 weeks. They seem to be more interested on whether you have major heart issues, diabetes, if you are on oxygen. You should give them a call. Allen

Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Welcome Brett, the rise in PSA could be due to a prostate infection. I was surprised your URO is only waiting 2 weeks after you stop the antibiotics to retest. I had a prostate infection 4 years ago and both my GP and Urologist said to wait at least 6 weeks before retesting as the antibiotics artificially lower the PSA number and it takes at least 6 weeks before they are totally out of your blood stream. Or that was the case with the silver bullets they gave me , yours may be different. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Title: Update from Manchester

Posts.Content: Scorpio, please don't let using a leg bag keep you from enjoying your usual way of life. I played golf with a guy wearing a leg bag, so realize there will always be a few who can't handle it but most men won't let a leg bag redefine their lives. It is an "inconvenience" not an explosive device. As far as night time sleeping goes just loop an elastic around the tubing and pin the elastic to the side of the bedding. This will allow you to roll over etc. Keep in mind your brain works even in sleep. I'm sure you don't roll over and fall out of bed, so your brain will keep you in check. For 2 weeks I slept on my back/left side/right side. Just don't stress over it. But keep in touch with friends, go to the movies, ball game , whatever. Do not hide at home. Good Luck B

Posts.Title: Awaiting remaing tests

Posts.Content: Scorpio, no worries my friend. Obviously you don't feel it when it's inserted and there is virtually no sensation when it is taken out. During the day you will wear a leg bag, at least when you go out. Make certain it is firmly secured and I recommend you empty it frequently. If it gets to full it can start to slide down your leg due to weight and when it reaches the end of its line you will feel a tug. But that's easily avoidable, I emptied mine when I thought it was a bit more than 1/2 full. Sleeping at night is not a major issue either.Just ensure there are no kinks in the line and the big bag is well below you for proper flow. I had mine in for 2 weeks and still enjoyed going out for lunch, movies, etc. The week will pass quickly. Ask your doctor what you should do in case of the catheter coming out (Highly unlikely). My surgeon did not want any RN or other person re-insurting it who wasn't part of his team and he gave me a 24/7 number to get hold of them. Good Luck B
Posts.Title: Catheter-How bad/uncomfortable is it? Or it's NOT that bad?

Posts.Content: Welcome dowtar, there are many excellent centers, in addition to the ones you mentioned there is the Mayo Clinic, but every major city usually has good urologists and oncologists. The doctor treating you is more important than the center, and it is important that you feel comfortable with them. You perhaps have friends who've had prostate cancer and you could ask them. However you are putting the cart way in front of the horse. What symptoms do you have? When was your last PSA and what was the number? Also, what makes you think you have prostate cancer? Take a breath and get checked out by your family doctor, starting with a DRE and a PSA test. If he/she feels there may be an issue, have her make an appointment with a urologist and an oncologist. Let us know how you make out Allen

Posts.Content: I know it's tough to get a feel for a specialist, especially if this is your first time. Many great surgeons have the personality of a wood chip..I have one of those , but he is a first class surgeon. Experience and results outweigh a smile. Why not just ask him how many procedures he has performed, what has been his success rate based on : survival, ED, Continence. They have this information and I'm sure he's been asked before so won't need to get back to you later. All the best Allen

Posts.Title: Radiation recovery time

Posts.Content: Thanks Sarg, I'm no physician but that seems like a high dosage. I was prescribed either 50mg of Viagra or 20mg of Cialis once/week. My doctor said this is part of the healing process and not intended to give you an erection at this point. I did read some time ago where a surgeon told his patient after about a year that the Viagra/Cialis had done all it was going to do as far as helping to heal damaged nerves and the person could begin taking it at his convenience for the purpose of erections if it worked. He also recommended the injections. My issue is if the pills have done all they can do in healing then why continue to purchase them for that purpose. I get great erections with injections and I could try a 100mg Viagra every couple of months to see if it worked . B

Posts.Content: Welcome Nighthiker, In my opinion you need to forget about AS with a Gleason of 7. I too was diagnosed with a Gleason of 7(3+4) and having the prostate removed was the smartest thing I've done. I met wit 2 very skilled surgeons and 1 very skilled oncologist at 2 different medical clinics. All three agreed that in their opinion AS was not a smart option for me. I do think about PSA a week before my testing, but I would far sooner have PSA in the back of my mind, then in my body steadily increasing. This is a serious choice you're making so get a few opinions from highly skilled surgeons and oncologists before deciding on AS. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Content: Welcome Valerie, I can understand your concern. It would seem that your doctor didn't do a great job of explaining all of this to you. It may be the that when he removed the cluster of 9 lymph nodes it was because they were the only ones that looked suspicious, and given 7 were clear he thinks he has gotten all of the cancer, and that may well be the case. I think a 2nd opinion would be a good idea and I would recommend an oncologist. Three months is a long to wait, and no doubt it is causing you and your husband an enormous amount of stress. Best of luck to you both Allen

Posts.Title: Lymph Node Metastasis

Posts.Content: Valerie, I believe you are correct with your comment on follow up by surgeons. Obviously many surgeons are good at follow up, many including mine was/is not. He is a brilliant surgeon, but when they roll you out of the operating room he thinks his job is over other than scheduled psa results. He did refer me to a great oncologist when I requested it, so now I alternate between them at 6 month intervals. You will need to take control of the situation and I suggest you ask the surgeon to refer you to an oncologist in your area. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Title: ED Meds Cost (Cialis)

Posts.Content: If you have been going to your GP for some years, just ask them for some samples. Usually they are happy to pass them out as the drug salesperson calls weekly and replenishes their inventory. Allen
Posts.Title: ED Meds Cost (Cialis)

Posts.Content: I briefly considered it out of curiosity. We have a Cleveland clinic in Toronto who does it but it just doesn't have enough historical data to make me feel comfortable with it. There is very little qualitative information on it. A lot of quantitative information but that to me is just fluff. I may be old fashioned but I like to take my lead from my urologist who is open and honest and lays out all the alternatives, makes his recommendation and then lets you decide. I would have no reason to second guess my doctor as he has spent years of time and tons of money getting an education. It may well be in 10 years they may have hard data that can show how proton beams is better overall than other options. Right now I just don't see it. B
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before my Proton Beam Treatments

Posts.Content: D Welcome to the group, sorry you need to be here. Others may have more knowledge and different opinion on your question, however to me your doctor's comment makes sense. It appears you had some degree of ED prior to surgery, and unfortunately although PC surgery can save your life it can't improve your sexual performance. I think you are going to find that all men here lost some degree of performance after surgery. There are meds such as Viagra, Cialis, Trimix that should allow you to have an enjoyable sex life. Good luck and be happy you caught the cancer at an early stage. Allen

Posts.Content: I briefly considered it out of curiosity. We have a Cleveland clinic in Toronto who does it but it just doesn't have enough historical data to make me feel comfortable with it. There is very little qualitative information on it. A lot of quantitative information but that to me is just fluff. I may be old fashioned but I like to take my lead from my urologist who is open and honest and lays out all the alternatives, makes his recommendation and then lets you decide. I would have no reason to second guess my doctor as he has spent years of time and tons of money getting an education. It may well be in 10 years they may have hard data that can show how proton beams is better overall than other options. Right now I just don't see it. B

Posts.Content: Great news Coors, look forward to your future reporting of all zeros. I have been using Trimix, the training will be about 10 minutes. She will show you how to draw the Trimix from the bottle and where to insert it. It will be on the side away from a vein, and you will alternate sides with each time you inject. They will start you at the lowest dosage and if you need to increase it then you can do that. After you inject it, she will leave while you stimulate yourself and then your DR or his resident will come in and caution you NOT to inject again until the next day and give you a script. It has to be refrigerated and the pharmacy should give it to you in a bag with an ice pack. I prefer to get a dozen syringes from pharmacy , fill them and freeze them. It keeps it @ 100% strength for a couple of months if needed. Also it will defrost in your hand in about 3-5 minutes. Allen

Posts.Title: Brand New

Posts.Content: Welcome John. I think personal health issues affect most people in a stressful way. Some can put it aside but I think they're in a minority. I tend to over think health issues and not necessarily in a positive way. I tend to run more, eat less and think of the negatives. Thank heavens my wife eventually gets me calmed down. Your PSA is a high number but it doesn't necessarily mean you have prostate cancer. My recommendation is that you keep as busy as possible , visit friends and relatives and in no time you will have a prognosis. If it turns out you do have PC then please return and let us know your Gleason score and as much other information as possible. This site is like a family for those of us with PC, you can get advice, empathy,and everything you'll need to help you get through this. Hoping you don't need to join us. Allen

Posts.Title: Brand New

Posts.Content: I wasn't prepared to wait until January for both ultrasound and Cysto so I went to my MD and got a requisition for an ultra sound and had it done on Friday. My doctor and urologist should get a copy of results on Mon or Tues. They did bladder, kidneys and whatever else. They did the 1st with bladder full and 2nd empty. As I was getting dressed the technician said (unsolicited) that the radiologist would review the pictures but he could see nothing "interesting" which made me feel significantly better. I did use all my initial antibiotics as directed and it did cure the UTI. The issue beyond occasional stabbing pain in the lower bladder/abdominal area is the trace amount (2%) of blood still being present. Today is my 4th day with zero "visible blood" in the urine and the stabbing pain is 60% less frequent and painful. Will let you know what comes from the ultra sound. Thank you all for taking the time to comment, it means a lot. Allen

Posts.Title: Robotic surgery vs hands

Posts.Content: After prostate cancer (3 years ago) when I had DiVinci followed a year later by 33 rounds of radiation, I may have another issue that I'm not ready for. While on vacation 6 weeks ago I noticed blood in urine. I went to ER of Florida hospital where they took a urine sample and drew 5 vials of blood. They said my blood work was perfectly normal but I had a raging UTI. After starting antibiotic could no longer see blood but after 6 days started seeing it again. Used remaining antibiotics and went back to ER. The UTI was was cleared up and they thought it was irritation. Decided to come back to Canada. Going for ultra sound today and a Cysto in January. I sometimes go 3-4 days and not see blood and if my bladder gets full, I get a stabbing pain in lower region and for sure there will be a lot of bright blood. As long as I empty bladder at about 25% there will be I don't see blood but it does show presence in urine analysis. Also if I lift anything heavy. Fingers crossed it's a polyp or kidney stone. Don't think I can battle cancer again. Allen

Posts.Title: BRACHY REPORT...6 Months Out

Posts.Content: After the catheter as removed I bought a very accurate food scale and measured every pad and diaper and kept track of the weight of the dry pad and at the end of the day I subtracted the dry weight from the wet weight and kept it on a calendar. I was going through 6-10 pads/day. I was faithful to my kegel exercises which I did 3 times a day. Week after week the pads were fewer. At the end of 7 weeks I was fully continent. I still continue the same kegel schedule. Good luck Allen

Posts.Title: Dont even know where to start

Posts.Content: Welcome Delta, Congratulations on successfully battling 2 cancers . In my case I was 65 when I had my Robotic prostatectomy..T3A, G(3+4). Immediately after surgery I leaked with the force of a water tap turned on full. However, I was diligent with my keagel exercises and saw a major improvement after 10 days and was fully continent after 7 weeks. Even all the nerves were spared on one side my ED persisted for months and Viagra had no impact. After 6 months I tried Trimix and it worked GREAT. It took another year before Viagra and Cialis worked almost as well. I still have occasions when I want to use Trimix so I alternate between Viagra and Trimix, using Trimix about 25% of the time. Be patient and everything will work out for you. Your body has been through a lot already. Allen

I sometimes go 3-4 days and not see blood and if my bladder gets full, I get a stabbing pain in lower region and for sure there will be a lot of bright blood. As long as I empty bladder at about 25% there will be I don't see blood but it does show presence in urine analysis. Also if I lift anything heavy. Fingers crossed it's a polyp or kidney stone. Don't think I can battle cancer again. Allen
Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Dave, you are an extremely brave, pragmatic man. I like your philosophy of wishing for the best and planning for the worst. I hope and pray your wish over rides your planning. Hopefully you are still here years from now giving first hand advice to men who find themselves where you are now. All the very best Allen
Posts.Title: Time,,Tic Toc, Tic Toc

Posts.Content: ZDog, you need to have it checked to see if it's a hematoma or a hernia. If it's a hematoma they will probably let it absorb into your body. If it were large they could choose to drain it. The more serious is a hernia, as it could strangulate the blood supply around the area. I had the same thing in the same place and it was a hematoma and they elected to let it drain. It took about 3-4 weeks. It is important you contact your doctor or it being the weekend visit the ER and see a Urologist on duty. They will probably do a cat scan . B

Posts.Title: Advice. Thoughts. Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer at 52 Gleason Score of 6,7 and 8..

Posts.Content: Welcome Delta, Congratulations on successfully battling 2 cancers . In my case I was 65 when I had my Robotic prostatectomy..T3A, G(3+4). Immediately after surgery I leaked with the force of a water tap turned on full. However, I was diligent with my keagel exercises and saw a major improvement after 10 days and was fully continent after 7 weeks. Even all the nerves were spared on one side my ED persisted for months and Viagra had no impact. After 6 months I tried Trimix and it worked GREAT. It took another year before Viagra and Cialis worked almost as well. I still have occasions when I want to use Trimix so I alternate between Viagra and Trimix, using Trimix about 25% of the time. Be patient and everything will work out for you. Your body has been through a lot already. Allen

Posts.Content: I had robotic surgery in 2012 and my psa remained at zero for 11 months. Then it went to 0.12 Although my surgeon wanted to watch it for some months , I wanted to start radiation asap. I had 33 rounds of radiation finishing at Christmas. My oncologist feels confident my psa will go to zero again. If it does that's fine, if it doesn't I assume HT is the next step. My Gleason score was 7 (3+4) Assuming my luck dealing with this PC has not been remarkable so far and that luck continues and I do have a psa higher than 0.0. Is HT the next logical step? How high does your psa need to reach before they start? How successful are they, and for how many years do they stay effective. What is the most effective Hormone Treatment? I realize some people have major side affects and others are only moderately bothered , given I had zero side effects from my radiation treatment, doubtful I would have a major issue with HT. I am still expecting/hoping that my radiation will have been successful. Brave

Posts.Content: Logic, .1 is when the cancer becomes "Detectable", your DR will probably want to do one more perhaps in a couple of weeks or maybe 1 month. If it climbs higher I suspect he will recomend Salvation radiation. It is painless, virtually no side effects and you should be right as rain afterwards. Posts.Content: PPicard, My first increase in PSA came on suddenly. My symptoms were increased urination, frequency, and pain when urinating. Posts.Title: Need a break

Posts.Content: Hi MM, welcome to our site. I too had radiation 11 months after surgery, thankfully the radiation has worked these past 3 years. I find it strange that an oncologist is suggesting your husband should check his recommendation with his urologist. I would have thought the urologist's job was over and further decisions would be between your husband and his oncologist. From your report it appears your husband's PSA was detectable immediately, unless you meant to report .01 instead of 0.1. Although some oncologists like to jump on PSA immediately when it reoccurs after radiation, many, including mine prefer to wait until the PSA hits 15-20 in order to prolong quality of life as long as possible and he has found it made no difference long term on the effectiveness of HT. Not sure I would be comfortable with that but I'm not an oncologist . I would get a 2nd opinion from another oncologist before agreeing to the wait. I wish your husband success with his choice and please keep us updated. Allen

Posts.Content: PPicard, My first increase in PSA came on suddenly. My symptoms were increased urination, frequency, and pain when urinating. It did turn out to be a prostate infection and antibiotics cleared it up, although it did take some weeks on them. My psa returned to normal levels and stayed there until 5 years later when I was diagnosed with pc. Keep an eye on your psa level and if it climbs even slightly I would suggest you may want to have a biopsy just for piece of mind. Good Luck B

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome Tiger. I started using Trimix about 6 months post Da Vinci. Your euro will know doubt send you to his RN or a resident to show you how to draw the trimix, where to insert the needle, etc. The only thing you really need to watch is that you alternate injection sites (left one time and right side next time. Also don't inject into a vein. The drug works in less than 5 min and lasts from 20 min to 45 min. Good Luck Allen
Posts.Title: 60 Minute Erections

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, My PSA reappeared approximately a year after surgery (DaVinci) I was a Gleason 7 (3+4) . I had 33 rounds of salvage radiation with virtually zero side effects other than 15 minutes of fatigue an hour after the last few treatments.. It has been almost 2 years since my radiation and my PSA is still undectable. Tell your friend to relax and enjoy life as he will have a long, long time to enjoy it...unless he dies of needless stress. I was 65 when I had surgery, 66 when I had radiation. When I'm 96 I will reflect on the few days I had stress and think : Why did I waste that week. It did not interfere with my erections, or continence. Hopefully this helps with his peace of mind. Allen

Posts.Title: Happy thanksgiving!

Posts.Content: Fred, I can appreciate your frustration. After my surgery incontinence wasn't discussed so I thought of it as an inconvenience measured in days not months. For the first month whatever I did (Standing, walking, coughing) resulted in me going through numerous pads/day. I kept up with my kegels and started to see a big improvement around week 5 . I cut out my daily glass of wine and was fully continent at the end of week 7. A friend of mine had RALPH the following year and was 5-6 months getting fully continent, but he hung in there and he is back to running and working out without leakage. So be patient my friend, for some it's a marathon but you will cross the finish line. Allen

Posts.Title: Getting tough to deal with

Posts.Content: Hi MM, welcome to our site. I too had radiation 11 months after surgery, thankfully the radiation has worked these past 3 years. I find it strange that an oncologist is suggesting your husband should check his recommendation with his urologist. I would have thought the urologist's job was over and further decisions would be between your husband and his oncologist. From your report it appears your husband's PSA was detectable immediately, unless you meant to report .01 instead of 0.1. Although some oncologists like to jump on PSA immediately when it reoccurs after radiation, many, including mine prefer to wait until the PSA hits 15-20 in order to prolong quality of life as long as possible and he has found it made no difference long term on the effectiveness of HT. Not sure I would be comfortable with that but I'm not an oncologist . I would get a 2nd opinion from another oncologist before agreeing to the wait. I wish your husband success with his choice and please keep us updated. Allen

Posts.Title: Thoughts on stopping HT and doing AS

Posts.Content: Coupe, I had my radiation done on the latest equipment and finished Dec 24/13. They will want you to have an empty bowel and will caution you most likely not to use an enema. My oncologist wanted me to take Milk of Magnesia in the evening. Also they will want your bladder quite full as it acts to hold the bowel out of the beams way. The worst part for me was keeping my body absolutely still for the few minutes the beam arcs over you twice. You are not strapped in, although they put a device on the metal table to help hold your legs quiet. However if you cough, sneeze or move any at all, you are off the table and the missed day will be rescheduled. For most men 70+ the worst was holding a full bladder for the duration of the test. They do a mini cat scan before starting the beam to ensure your bowel and bladder are as they should be. The marking to tattoo you for the radiation is no big deal. They do it a few days prior to start of radiation.
Posts.Title: A bowel movement before each radiation treatmen; how

Posts.Content: Jim, A couple of the older guys(70+) who I would bump into at the hospital would loved to have had your oncologist. I can only assume your bladder wasn't full when they did the markings and put the tattoos on you. It is critical the level of fluid in your bladder be consistent with the markings at each session, otherwise down the road you could have bladder/bowel issues because the beam could missed the mark due to the bladder not being exactly where it was during the marking. I guess that's also why they like it full, the individual knows he is ok once her starts squirming and sweating due to the fact he thinks he will pee himself. Allen

Posts.Content: I agree excessive exercise like excessive anything can be detrimental to ones health. Having said that we need to keep in mind that "excessive" is a moving target. Based on one's age, physical condition, exercise history, etc , where 30 min may be excessive for one man, 60 minutes may be just fine for another. In most cases your body will let you know when you are pushing your limits. I recall reading where John Kerry did very strenuous mountain biking frequently, and started shortly after Robotic Surgery. He appears to be doing fine. Arnold Palmer returned to golfing at age 65 shortly after prostate surgery and any golfer who has walked and played 18 holes knows how strenuous that is, especially for amateurs. B B

Posts.Content: Welcome Island time. In my case I met with 2 qualified Urologists and a skilled oncologist who only worked with prostate cancer patients. I elected to go with the surgery (DiVinci) based on the fact that should my cancer re-appear I could get radiation treatment. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Content: An article from the internet that may be somewhat of interest: How does clamping work?” Here is a plausible theory: ◾Clamping restricts blood from flowing out of the penis while still allowing limited inflow. Because blood is still flowing into the penis, and none is leaving, there is an extraordinary amount of pressure built up. ◾The pressure built up while clamping expands penis tissues beyond its normal erection state. By expanding the penis tissues multiple times, the expansion eventually becomes permanent

Posts.Content: Welcome Robert to the best PC site available. Most have the surgery over radiation, that will become clear to you when you read the posts. Having said that, my surgeon told me 18 months ago that radiation was also very effective but they hadn't been keeping records as long as they have for surgery. He said by 2020 when they have enough data on radiation it may be shown they are equal in curing or treating PC. He also said if you are considering radiation and it doesn't work you can't fall back on Robotic Surgery due to the damage radiation does. However if you go with Robotic Surgery and it doesn't work you can have radiation. I suggest you seek out and meet with a good surgeon, and a good oncologist, and have them go over your records and give you their opinion. After asking them numerous questions you can make a more knowledgeable decision. Good Luck Brave

I'm not sure if open surgery could be done. Obviously radiation is less invasive than surgery but the side affects (ED, Incontinence) are still there. After consideration I chose surgery mostly as it left me a follow up procedure (radiation) if required... and it was. Allen

Posts.Title: PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hello White. I was 65 when diagnosed with PC. I had zero symptoms but my psa had risen. I ended up with a cancer volume of 15% and a gleason of 7. After the robotic surgery , Oct, 2012 I was feeling great. My surgeon did say ED and incontinence would be short term. After 18 months I still have ED, however I was fully continent in 7 weeks. My psa remained at 0 for almost a year and then went to 0.15. Surgeon wanted to wait and see time frame for doubling, I told him no way and book me an appointment with the best oncologist he knew. I went ahead with 33 sessions of radiation . I finished treatment on Dec 24th and headed to our place in Florida at end of December. After being there for 3 + months came home and had my blood work done. Met with oncologist today and my psa is 0.0. Many will disagree, but I am a firm believer not all prostate cancers are slow growing , and they will not be easier to treat 3 or 6 months after a rise in psa. I personally do not feel I would have got a reading of 0.0 had I waited and observed doubling time. Just my opinion B

Posts.Title: Nail-biting wait for PSA results....11 month post-op

Posts.Content: I certainly sympathise with your situation. Personally I never found it useful counting pads as I used them and changed them long before I needed to simply because it played with my head having urine somewhere in my pads. Another person may wear them until they are full. So he may go through 4 pads a day while I leaked less but went through 10 pads. It is imperative that your husband faithfully do his kegel exercises. Also you need to have a frank discussion with his urologist and ask him for viable options. In the short term you need something to put over the depends like a baby used to wear over a diaper. I don't think it's uncommon for leakage @ 3 months post op so don't give up hope. I was fortunate to be continent at 7 weeks due entirely I think to kegel exercises which I performed an hour a day broken into 3- 20 minute segments. My thoughts are with you I am sure this is taking a heavy toll on you as well. I would not recommend you try clamps or anything similar until you run it all past his urologist, you do not want to make things worse. Good Luck & Hugs. B

Posts.Content: In hindsight I would probably opt for regular prostate surgery were I able to turn back the clock.On the upside I was fully continent in 7 weeks and had zero problems with incontinence since. Your surgeon should be able to tell you accurately how long your surgery will be, he has seen the results of all your tests, cat scans, etc. B
Posts.Title: How long is surgery?

Posts.Content: Great news pratoman, I wish you continued success
Posts.Title: PSA Results

Posts.Content: I thought my blood in the urine issue was behind me after the antibiotic cleared my UTI, however I am still having occasional blood in urine. Went to ER back in London and they did another urine analysis on Friday plus they are going to book me for a Cysto. The DR I saw thought it could be irritation caused by scarring on the bladder from salvage radiation 2 years ago. Just wondering if anyone else had this issue? Allen
Posts.Title: Scarring after radiation

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome goldbass. Congratulations on 14 years with no change to PSA, I'm urea it was a shock to find it climbed. My PSA climbed after a year post surgery and I had 33 rounds of radiation. Sixteen months later my PSA is 0.0. Similar to Jim I had no side affects. Neither my ED or Continence was affected. They have come light years with radiation treatments. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Thanks Fairwind, hopefully that's my problem as well. When I went a month ago to an ER in Florida and went on bactericine for 10 days. It cleared the infection but there was still some blood in the urine. It was visible about once every 15 times to the washroom. Now that I have stopped the 8-10 mile daily power walks and heavy lifting , it does not happen as often nor is there as much blood. I had blood work done in Florida and hemoglobin and everything else (5 viles) was perfectly normal.

Posts.Title: Mr. Softee still in Zero Club

Posts.Content: Just to set a base line I was 185 pounds at time of surgery, and fluctuated between 182 and 187 for the next couple of years. Then my back started to act up forcing me to cut back on running and my weight spiked to 195-197. I am back now to 183 and can comfortably climb into the vette.
Posts.Title: Link between weight and leakage?

Posts.Content: Hi Logic, my #1 concern would be the experience of the radiology team, if you have any doubts about that you should travel the 75 miles. I would hope your 2nd appointment is with a urologist who is well experienced with PC. I'm not putting down radiation but I would consider surgery where you have a second kick at the cat with radiation if necessary. This is very seldom true in reverse. I know people who had radiation and they experienced the same degree of incontinence and ED as those who had surgery. You have time to meet with several doctors until you find one you have a good comfort level with. Good luck and best of health in 2015 Allen
Posts.Title: What questions should I ask a radiology oncologist?

Posts.Content: My urologist did not recommend any change to the well balanced diet I dad always eaten. Fibre contains a lot of carbs which can lead to weight gain unless you are quite active and burning the calories. I have never seen any concensus that any type of diet is better than just following the RDA for the food groups.
Posts.Title: "Plenty of Fiber"

Posts.Content: OTAGO...If you reread my comment I doubt you will even see the word "calories" plus the take away for most people is that my doctor said to stick with a "well balanced diet" based on Recommended Daily Average for types of foods as I have always done. He did not want me dramatically adding fibre for any reason. He did reco. short term use of a stool softener if needed.

Posts.Title: 6 months Post-Op and nervous about PSA

Posts.Content: Welcome chasisme. I'm certain you will get the advice you are looking for here. It does seem out of place that a Uro is recommending Radiation, that is what you would expect from an Oncologist. M gleason score was also 3+4 and I had DaVinci (Robotic) surgery Oct 2012. If I were you I'd find a Urologist who "Specialized" in prostate cancer. I'm sure you live somewhere close to a major hospital facility with a good urology dept. I would have that meeting first and get his opinion on our best option and from there you can meet with an oncologist who "specializes" in prostate cancer. Remember this is YOUR LIFE and you don't want to settle for generalists but rather specialists. Ask questions as they come to you and good luck. Allen

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: It has been 18 months since my surgery, My psa was undetectable for a year and the went to 0.17, I then had 33 rounds of radiation which ended Dec 24th. I am still working on getting over the shock of having PC. The oncologist feels confident that my next psa in 2 weeks (1st since radiation) will be fine. But that's what my surgeon said after the Di Vinci operation My gleeson was 7......3 + 4 and I was T3A whatever that is about. The cancer had spread just outside the prostate but went no further. My surgeon was CONFIDENT he got it all, apparently not. I am 67 and would like to think I had 10+ years left but this crap is stressful. Brave

Posts.Content: I think there is a place for Holistic approach, although not sure where if you aren't Suzanne Summers. If you have PC I can't imagine any nutrients that are going to cure it. Certainly eating healthy foods and exercise will be beneficial to your overall health. Before you spend a ton of money on supplements, etc. I suggest you have your doctor make an app't with a urologist and ask their opinion on how to reduce psa. How high is your psa currently? How high was it on your previous psa test? Brave

Posts.Title: New here, Prostectomy complete

Posts.Content: Hi Bob, I was advised that the numbers weren't in yet but my DR felt beam radiation could be as effective as surgery when they collected enough data. I elected to go with Robotic surgery and my psa started to reappear after 11 months. I then had beam radiation done and a year later my psa is 0.0. The side affects from 33 rounds of radiation were virtually none. Were I to be able to go back in time, my 1st choice would be radiation. Allen
Posts.Title: External beam radiation: side effects, experiences?

Posts.Content: Rlyons, you have my sympathy man. I know a few guys who have minor side affects from HT, but the majority ask themselves daily "Is it worth it"? Like you, they hang in there in hope that a Hormone drug will be introduced soon with far less side affects. Unfortunately PC doesn't get a fraction of the research budget that breasts cancer does. I'm not looking for any $ to be taken from breast cancer but it would be nice if more research $ were spent on PC. B
Posts.Title: WHY is there no sticky on HT

Posts.Content: dirkv, I can only respond to your question on radiation treatment. I had 33 sessions with virtually no side effects. After 25 sessions I noticed I would have a little fatigue on Friday (last session of the week). When I got home sometimes I took a 15 min nap but most of the time I got on the treadmill and got my heart rate up. By Sat morning I was 100%. Other than that zero side affects. It didn't interfere with my lifestyle, including sex at all. Brave

Posts.Title: new member

Posts.Content: Hello Deb, I find it interesting how urologist's are different with Kegel's. My Dr wants my 3 sets per day all standing. He has a particular dislike for the "clutch method" that Mayo likes. The clutch method is where you sit and raise the pelvic floor from 0% to 100% hold 10 seconds and repeat 6 additional times. Your hubby should follow his doctor's recon. but you would think they could come up with a Standard.

Posts.Content: as far as I remember ip6 is another vitamin that claims to assist people with cancer, and I don't think there has ever been a scientific study done to show it helps at all. If the medical profession has done studies on it then I would enjoy reading them. B
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and IP6?

Posts.Content: With all due respect, I doubt IP6 could even slow down the growth of any cancer. I have searched the internet and have not found any credited medical research company who shows any verifiable proof of IP6 curing, or slowing the growth of cancer. B
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and IP6?

Posts.Content: I read the link and see zero results for treatment results on HUMANS, I apologize if I missed it. Many scientific/medical meds are started on animals only to find out later they do not repeat the same success in humans. I think if IP6 showed it helped men with prostate cancer, a major drug company would have refined it, got FDA approval, and started marketing it. We read about so many old beliefs about the benefits of things that people believed because some type of doctor wearing a white coat, and stethoscope said it was a cure for x, y z . I think before these links are even posted, the Gov't should make the institution behind them post at the beginning in BOLD print. NOT FDA APPROVED, NEVER TESTED ON HUMANS, then if the person want to find out what they're testing on monkeys, rats, pigs, etc they can read the article.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and IP6?

Posts.Title: Holistic approach

Posts.Content: I'm sure some people who take it as part of a healthy diet may get some benefit, however perhaps not as much as from the other fruits and vegetables. Were it to have some major impact on its own I think it would have been tested with PC patients in some type of blind study and post results. However it is a powerful tool even if it just makes PC patients believe it is helping them, and so long as it's not hurting them. I say go for it. B

Posts.Title: RALP surgery on 4/18

Posts.Content: Other than inconvenience I had no issue with the bag. At night use the large bag, and have our partner clip the tube somewhere on the bedding so that you won't turn quickly and possibl pull the catheter. She used to do this with patients. DO NOT let the small leg bag get too full as it puts stress on the velcros straps and they may start slipping downwards putting stress on the catheter where it fits into your penis. Other than that just get on with life.The bag is a 2 week inconvenience. My wife told me when the surgeons nurse removed it I would not even feel it...she was 100% right. I was waiting for a bit of a tug but nothing. She just said "We're Done"

Posts.Title: New Member here - my story.

Posts.Content: Hello caregiver, after 11 months post surgery, my psa went to 0.17. I decided on radiation and had 33 treatments. A year later my psa is 0.0. There will be two tattoos, one will be in his pubic hair on the left, the other on the right. They are so small as to be practically invisible. He needn't worry about anyone seeing them, they are the Size of an ink dot. He won't have any problem driving and there won't be any radiation burns. I am fully continent, and can now achieve an erection without Cialis or Viagra. Really no side affects. Towards the end , treatment 26-33 I was a bit fatigued but it lasted 15 minutes. After my last treatment I had a coffee and drove 3 hours to visit my kids and was fine. Hope this helps a bit. Allen

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> Towards the end   treatment 26 33 I was a bit
Towards the end   treatment 26 33 I was a bit fatigued

Posts.Title: Radiation 2.5 years after prostectomy... Questions

Posts.Content: 1). I never took HT with my radiation. 2) Absolutely no bowel issues or bladder issues after treatments. It is imperative that your bowel be empty and your bladder be full during your time on the treatment table. They do a mini cat scan each time to ensure the above has been carried out. The full bladder pushes your bowel out of the way, eliminating radiation damage. I got to know a dozen guys taking treatment when I did. The only complaint was from the older men 70+ who had a hard time with a full bladder for the 10 minutes. None in my group mentioned any bladder, bowel issues during treatment. Not sure how they fared down the road but doubtful they had an issue post treatment. Allen

Posts.Title: I've been pad free now for a month or so

Posts.Content: Had my 2nd and final Cysto today to confirm blood in urine. It turns out that salvage radiation scarred a couple of blood vessels in my bladder. When I lifted objects 50 + pounds it caused at least one blood vessel to burst. The blood layed there in the bladder until I got a bladder infection. All else turned out fine and no current bleeding and shouldn't be any going forward as long as I restrict my lifting to 25-30 pounds maximum. On the upside I have an excuse not to carry my wife's shopping bags. Allen

Posts.Title: Post-DaVinci catheter tricks?

Posts.Content: Squiggle, I know exactly how your dad feels. I had a urologist tell me I could probably go 5-10 years before needing surgery. I said no and had surgery (with a different surgeon) a couple of months later. He told me I was lucky I didn't wait with a Gleason of 8 which was revised down to 7. After 1 year of psa at zero the test showed it had jumped (4 months) to 0.17. I told him I wanted radiation asap and am now finishing my treatment (3 left). I was totally enraged at several doctors starting with my GP who saw my psa rising and didn't send me to a urologist earlier, then the urologist telling me we could watch and wait, and thirdly the surgeon who did the surgery but didn't get all the cancer. When you are faced with cancer I think it is normal when treatments don't work to strike out at somebody. I wish your father all the best going forward and his radiation takes his psa to zero over time. B

My surgeon told me that if mine ever came out, or began to hurt I was to call (he gave me a card) his number and he or one of his Interns or nurse would arrange to meet me and have the problem corrected, and that one of them would be available 24/7. Posts.Title: Zero club or not?

Posts.Content: I am 66 and just finished my 29th treatment out of 33 this morning. So far I have had zero side affects with the exception of some fatigue at the end of each week. Usually I just get on the tread mill and walk it off. I know a few of the people I've met at treatment had diahrea but I would say only 5%. The worst part is having a FULL bladder at the time of treatment. If your bladder isn't full they take you off the table and wait 30 min while drinking more water. Also your bowel has to be as close to empty as possible. Your dad should get through it just fine, after a couple of treatments he will know exactly how much water to drink and when to start. The full bladder pushes the surrounding organs away from the radiation site. Hope this was somewhat helpful. B

Posts.Content: DR. Gary Elkins PHD at the Baylor University Research Center found in his initial study, that hypnosis brought about a 75% reduction in the amount of Hot Flashed men experienced, mostly due to HT. Posts.Title: I can now sleep

Posts.Content: Just heard from my Urologist's secretary and she confirmed that my PSA test that I had done yesterday morning came back undetectable. I must confess that I don't really control the stress well in the 5 days leading up to the test. Mostly due to my concern over the possibility of needing HT. My next test will be done in 6 1/2 months just a few weeks short of my 70th birthday. I now look forward to heading to our winter home and escaping the cold Canadian winter in Oct. Will now make dinner reservations for my wife and I at her favorite restaurant. Not sure I could survive the stress a week before testing without her support and calmness. It also helps she is an RN. Allen

My ED and Continence worked out well quickly so no worries, but I have a couple of friends who have little quality in their lives due to HT. Posts.Title: Hello

Posts.Content: I echo Lil Dog's comments. My wife was an RN in community nursing for some years and had many cancer patients. One she commented on was a 47 year old man with PC. He had 2 teenage daughters but unfortunately wasn't diagnosed in time to take any type of treatment. He became a community patient in the last 6 months of his life. He led a mostly normal life at home until a month before passing. He then went to a Hospice where all his requirements were looked after by great doctors, nurses, staff. They kept him comfortable until the end. Let's give your doctor the benefit of the doubt and expect you will get another year. A lot of new drugs and advancements can brought to market in a year. Brendan, you are in my prayers. Allen

Posts.Content: Time, I believe it is usually because of an issue with the pudendal nerve(Alcock Syndrome)most times it is temporary. Some things that could cause it are: men's use of rings during sex, sitting for long periods of time, poor posture, and even the side affect of radiation treatment on the prostate. I am sure you will get a significant amount of answers/opinions on this topic. I've never experienced it first hand but perhaps some men here have and can shed more light on it for you. Good Luck B

Posts.Content: As a user of TriMix I would recommend you empty your bladder, then lay on your bed and have your wife give you the injection. I do this because my hand will shake nervously and I will miss the target or jab to hard. You can't push the needle in to far. ALSO make certain you are using the smallest needle possible. I use a 30G. The syringe the pharmacy will give you is a 25G x5/8(0.5mm x 16mm) that size is required to go through the cork and withdraw the TriMix. Then once you have the desired amount in the syringe you switch the needle portion to a 30G. Needless to say the area where you do this should be very clean. We draw all the needles at the same time and freeze them. It takes only a minute to unthaw it while you hold it in your hand. I have never experienced any pain with injection. It does help that my wife is an RN. Good luck Allen

Posts.Content: Diet may help some people, but did nothing for me. Coming from the East Coast I grew up drinking tea versus coffee. As I got in my 20's -50's I drank about 6-8 cups of green tea/day and always had a glass of tomato juice with breakfast. And I got PC. Most of my friends drank black coffee and never had tea in their lives...cancer free. Personally I think if you are predisposed to get PC, there is little to nothing you can do but enjoy life and see what happens Allen

Posts.Content: Welcome Jeff, most of us have gone through where you are now. My DR continued to tell me every year that my prostate was small, soft, and smooth and my PSA was in the normal range. I felt there was something wrong and insisted on a biopsy which confirmed my worst suspicion..I had PC and it was G7(3+4). I had DaVinci in 2012 followed by salvage radiation in 2013. Knock on wood to date I am cancer free. I too looked on the Internet and found some dark, scary places when I was looking for info on PC. Luckily a friend recommended this site and what I've learned here is priceless. As you've found us then you're already a step in the right direction. Waiting is hard on us all my friend but more often then not the news you get is good. Hang in there and keep us in the loop. Good luck Allen

Posts.Content: Not sure why some get hung up on a number. What it the number was 1200 but 300 of the surgeries did not turn out well for the patient? I do think it's important the surgeon be in a major center and perform the MAJOR portion of the surgery. Keep in mind the surgeon has residents there who have to learn and so they do part of the surgery. I would be confident with a surgeon at a major hospital who has done 500+ surgeries and did most of it himself. Also he should have a good track record of success and they all know what their % is. Posts.Content: Congratulations on the downgrade Rick. Unfortunately incontinence after surgery is a marathon not a sprint. As far as feeling the need to urinate that will obviously be there, but so too will be many occasions in the early weeks where you have no feeling of urgency, but you leak. Kegel exercises are your main tool get get continent asap. I followed my exercise routine to the letter and was continent in 7 weeks. I was 65 at the time and my Gleason score was (3+4). I think measuring the weight of your pads/pull ups is a great idea. I did it and it was encouraging to observe progress. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Title: New and Unsure

Posts.Content: g steve, you have a lot going for you, especially your age, however 4 mos is extremely optimistic to expect to be at pre-op functioning. I had my surgery a year ago and am finding even Viagra/Cialis not all that dependable. My surgeon did tell me to expect 12-18 mos so fingers crossed I'll get there. Do not expect when you get there that ejaculations will be intense, I have yet to hear anyone say they were as intense as pre-surgery...But they are good. I take injections 2-3 times a week and they work great. You should expect to get a good erection and hold it approx. an hour (some longer some a bit shorter time. Now is the time to practice patience, it will come in the meantime you may get good results from Viagra or injections. Many of us use Trimix. Good Luck B

Posts.Content: Ralph are you measuring your leakage? It is a good way of tracking pace of improvement. Get a food scale and a zip loc bag. Weigh your dry pad every morning in the zip loc bag, and at night put your used pad(s) in the zip loc and weigh them. Obviously the difference is the weight of urine. Keep a record of it daily and review weekly. Hope this helps. Allen

Posts.Title: Following up after a long layoff

Posts.Content: Welcome PecenkA. Obviously you're aware that having a Gleason 9 is serious . Your dad seems to be keeping himself well informed on the disease and treatment options, so I am a bit confused as to what side effects he thinks he will experience with radiation ? There was a time many years ago that radiation did cause many people bad side effects especially with the bowel and bladder, but with the new equipment today radiation is mostly just an inconvenience. You might want to get your dad to update himself with the newest equipment and meet with an oncologist who works exclusively with prostate cancer. Best of luck to your dad and you. Allen
Posts.Title: Dad's post op diagnosis question

Posts.Content: Welcome Ron, until you get information back from testing you shouldn't worry at all, and even then you may find there is nothing to worry about. I was finally diagnosed with a biopsy. My MD sent me to a urologist because my PSA went from 3.2 to 6.1 in a year. The urologist did a DRE and said my prostate was small, soft and felt normal. I had no symptoms, my flow was good, no increased frequency or discomfort of any type. My urologist said we could wait a year and check again. I insisted on a biopsy and the results were I had PC, G8. After surgery it was changed to G7(3+4). My point is nothing is ruled out until proper testing is done. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Title: ED and Cymbalta

Posts.Content: g steve, you have a lot going for you, especially your age, however 4 mos is extremely optimistic to expect to be at pre-op functioning. I had my surgery a year ago and am finding even Viagra/Cialis not all that dependable. My surgeon did tell me to expect 12-18 mos so fingers crossed I'll get there. Do not expect when you get there that ejaculations will be intense, I have yet to hear anyone say they were as intense as pre-surgery...But they are good. I take injections 2-3 times a week and they work great. You should expect to get a good erection and hold it approx. an hour (some longer some a bit shorter time. Now is the time to practice patience, it will come in the meantime you may get good results from Viagra or injections. Many of us use Trimix. Good Luck B

Posts.Title: New Guy just diagnosed in 12/13

Posts.Content: Centsible, welcome to the premier site to help with your PC issues. Incontinence following removal of catheter is probably the #1 issue every guy has . In my case the first 2 weeks were much like you describe. By week 4 I could see the light at the end of the tunnel . By the end of week 7 I was fully continent. Many on here became continent quicker and for others it took longer than 7 weeks. You seem to be doing everything right, I assume you are avoiding lifting heavy issues and sitting for long periods. Make sure you go for a short walk every 90 minutes or less, just a walk around the house for 10 minutes will help. The main thing is have "patience". Your plumbing has experienced a major shock, and you need to give it time to heal. Feel free to bring questions here because there is nothing you are going through that numerous others haven't before you. Misery does like company at times. Good Luck Allen
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Incontinence

Posts.Content: Marve, I am very surprised your oncologist did a PSA shortly after completion of radiation. My oncologist, and most of the ones I've hear about wait 3 months after completion of radiation to test PSA because it takes that long to get an accurate reading. I would expect in a few months the number will be much lower. Allen '
Posts.Title: Question again....PSA?

Posts.Content: I had no ED issues prior to surgery and enjoyed sex at least twice a week. The doctor felt I should be able to perform without Viagra 8-12 months post surgery. It is now 14 months post surgery and neither Viagra or Cialis help, however when I went to penile injections (TRIMIX) I was like 22 again. It could be that I was 65 when I had the surgery and so Viagra will take longer or I may always the injections. Actually I'm not bothered by it as the injections work fine and we're back to at least twice a week + I stay hard when vertical or horizontal for an hour. I have recently had to bump the dosage to 0.15 but no big deal at all. B

Posts.Title: incision pain

Posts.Content: Hi Maverick, you might want to ask your radiologist about the likely hood of scarring the bladder. I had 2 occasions with blood in the urine, and one resulted in a bladder infection. After 2 ultrasounds and 2 cystoscope, it was determined to be some scarring from the radiation on the bladder. Apparently this isn't uncommon and effects you only when you strain yourself, like lifting something heavy. The radiation scars weaken some of the arteries in the bladder , if it happens to often it could seriously impede the flow of urine. Or so I have been told. It could be I am the only one to have this issue. Allen
Posts.Title: Day seven of forty

Posts.Content: Ralph, I never had any bowel issues after surgery, but even following my continence it felt as if my bladder was full and when I hit the washroom only squeezed out a few drops. I seldom experience anymore, but occasionally do.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Incontinence

Posts.Content: Centsible, you may be making some progress but not aware of it. You might want to get a food type scale, and keep accurate measurement of your leakage. It will even help when communicating with your doctor. Weigh zip lock bag as well as a dry pad or pull up. As you change pads put the wet ones in the bag and weigh them each night before bed. Deduct the weight of the bag plus the dry pads/pull ups. The difference is your leakage. Keep track of the number daily. You really can't go by amount of pads used as some will be wetter than others. Good Luck Allenī

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed. now what?

Posts.Content: I would advise you to consider surgeons/radiologists publications as a form of self promotion. There are some who skew the results by selecting patients, etc. I suggest you go by word of mouth by patients to start, from there you can set up appointments and see who you are comfortable with. You shouldn't have a hard time finding a good doctor in your state. I'm sure there are some here who can give you the names of doctors/hospital. I would prefer that to self promotion Brave
Posts.Title: How do you choose the right surgeon and hospital to perform a daVinci Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Sorry you had to join our society due to PC, having said that you are in the best possible place for advice and opinions from men who have been there. I don't believe there is a Best doctor or hospital. Every major city has excellent facilities and doctors. The important thing is to take a deep breath and be thankful they found it when they did. My Gleason was 7 and I had surgery 18 months ago. I was incontinent for 7 weeks, and I still have ED however trimix gets me as hard as a teenager. I think most on here would agree that getting rid of the cancer trumps ED or Incontinence concerns. I suggest you find an experienced urologist in a major city and discuss your condition, ask him all the questions that you want answers to. By the way, for what it's worth when I had my surgery I shared a room with a 30 year old man who had PC surgery. With all the options available today you should be able to dance at your grandkids wedding. All the best Brave

Posts.Title: 1st PSA 3 months post RALP = 0.3. What to do?

Posts.Content: Angelmum, similar to Jim, I had radiation (33) about 8 months ago. My psa is now 0.0 and I feel great. Your uncle doesn't have to be an athlete, and assuming his BP and cholesterol are fine on meds he should be fine, especially if he gets in some daily walks or other low impact exercise. The treatments are over in a matter of 10 minutes and none of the guys I got to know there, like me, had no side affects beyond temporary fatigue which passes quickly. I was 66 and by far the youngest person in the group I got to know taking treatments. One gentleman was 81 and showed up with his wife. He was having 45 treatments and was doing fine. Best of luck Allen

Posts.Title: PSA, 8 weeks post Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Steve, congratulations on your recovery. I think when most of us reflect on our PC procedures it seems like a Very bad dream. You are going to an A-1 facility for your follow up next month. I wish you continued clear readings and good health. Allen
Posts.Title: It's been a year.....

Posts.Content: Welcome Chief, we were all faced with the same dilema. I decided on Robotic Surgery vs radiation as the surgeons told me if radiation didn't work they would not do robotic surgery after. However if you go with the surgery and it doesn't work then you can go with the radiation afterwards. Having said that the side affects of radiation are much less than surgery of any kind. Give it some thought, talk to a surgeon and an oncologist and decide. B
Posts.Title: Just Found Out

Posts.Content: Welcome Tripp, sorry to see anyone having to be here but this site will provide you with a wealth of knowledge. I imagine your biggest concern right now is figuring out your options. We can help with that and many other things. We are here for you. Good Luck Allen
Posts.Title: Newbie

Posts.Content: Monday @ 10:30 Am I get my 6 month PSA reading. I have no reason to believe it still isn't undetectable, but I went to bed with it on my mind and woke up with it on my mind. Wish I could just shrug it off and ignore it but that's easier said than done.

AgeInfo.Phrase: to build Monday @ 10 30 Am I get my 6

Posts.Title: Stress starting to build

Posts.Content: Thanks fairwind, I had the blood drawn 2 weeks ago, just started to think about it yesterday. Wish I could shake it. I have never even thought about what people do when psa starts to climb, I suppose most get radiation at some point. Hopefully that isn't an issue for me.
Posts.Title: Stress starting to build

Posts.Content: I only get the PSA results from my surgeon on clinic day (Always Monday).His office gives me the date of my appointment and reminds me that the blood test is to be done at least 2 weeks prior. During my app't I get a mini physical, answer questions re ED and continence, updates me on any new developments in treatment if there are any, and he wants to ensure I am still doing my Kegel exercises. He always insists the blood draw be done at the same clinic. Even when I had a catheter in following surgery he told me that if it fell out to call is office (s4 hours/day) and he or one of his residents would meet me at the hospital and put it back in. M wife is a Registered Nurse and he wouldn't let her to replace it if it came out. B
Posts.Title: Stress starting to build

Posts.Content: The short answer is no, he doesn't require the radiation "immediately". Firstly you should have the test done again to verify the numbers. If the numbers are correct then you and your "Oncologist" can determine when to do the radiation. I had mine done at 0.17 that was 2 years ago and I'm still "undetectable". Good Luck Allen
Posts.Title: 1st PSA 3 months post RALP = 0.3. What to do?

Posts.Content: I never heard of it prior to reading it here, but it seems the Choline C-11 PET scan would be a welcome alternative to HT for many who are within range of a clinic that has one, and wants to delay the side affects of HT as long as possible.
Posts.Title: PSA rise after SRT are there tests to track down where the rising PSA is "lurking"

Posts.Content: You may want to have him checked out by an oncologist and find out if he is a good candidate for radiation treatments. If he is then talk it over with your uncle and the rest of the family. He is 78 in fairly good shape, ultimately the decision needs to be his. B

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or hormone therapy at age 78

Posts.Content: Angelmum, welcome. Other than your uncle's age and the fact he has pc, how would you classify his health? Does he have any issues with BP or heart issues? Is he active and exercising regularly? A healthy, active 78 year old could be a better candidate for radiotherapy than a 68 year old couch potato. I know many doctors try to candy coat the side affects of HT, but as you point out there is nothing sweet about it. B

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or hormone therapy at age 78

Posts.Content: Steve, you could be shown by your urologist, or his nurse the proper way to fill the syringe and where to inject it. If you find it impossible to do this perhaps your wife would be more then happy to inject you, given the alternative. The needle is so fine and gets injected just under the skin so it is virtually painless. Given your age and assuming your wife is in the same age bracket you are missing out on a lot of sex, which is a great stress reliever among other benefits. Allen

Posts.Title: Stress is over for another 6 months

Posts.Content: Hi JD. I have a G7(3+4) and personally I would not want to wait almost 3 months for surgery. If you were a 3+3 I think that would be different. I realize PC is a slow mover however at some point in time it could escape the gland. The nurse no doubt must feel comfortable you are not in any risk of that happening, but I'd feel better hearing it directly from the surgeon. Good Luck Allen

Posts.Content: Welcome pch. Although a PSA of 118 doesn't confirm PC, it does require a biopsy asap. If three weeks is the earliest date your urologist can get you in, then as stressful as it will be, you may have to go with it. Perhaps a urologist in another city could get you in a few days earlier, but the difference of 2 or 3 days will make little change. In Canada 3 weeks is about average. Having said that you should make certain you are on a cancellation list. Good Luck B

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or hormone therapy at age 78

Posts.Content: Angelmum, similar to Jim, I had radiation (33) about 8 months ago. My psa is now 0.0 and I feel great. Your uncle doesn't have to be an athlete, and assuming his BP and cholesterol are fine on meds he should be fine, especially if he gets in some daily walks or other low impact exercise. The treatments are over in a matter of 10 minutes and none of the guys I got to know there, like me, had no side affects beyond temporary fatigue which passes quickly. I was 66 and by far the youngest person in the group I got to know taking treatments. One gentleman was 81 and showed up with his wife. He was having 45 treatments and was doing fine. Best of luck Allen

Posts.Title: Viagra Use Linked With Increased Risk for Melanoma

Posts.Content: theszak, I have visited several sites in the past 18 months and I belong to this site and one other. In my opinion for what it's worth, this site has the others beat, hands down. There are more prostate posts here, there are far more topics on prostate issues here. Some other sites operate like a "Good Old Boys" site, this site doesn't. You will get more intelligent answers from members on this site than you will from any other I have visited. B
Posts.Title: Besides the great forum here what others are among the available resources?...

Posts.Content: On question#1, you should look for an oncologist who has been in the field at least 5 years and deals with prostate cancer exclusively. The equipment is very important. I honestly forget the one m oncologist used but it was the latest model developed. My side affects were zero and after 33 rounds and 15 months later my PSA is 0.0 It had previously climbed to 0.17 a year after surgery. My Gleason was 7; (3+4). Unfortunately I can't offer advice on question #2 Good Luck Allen
Posts.Title: Questions about salvage radiation therapy and the Mayo Clinic...

Posts.Content: Congratulations, and have the best time ever on your December cruise. You are an outstanding team who enjoy seeing the glass 1/2 full. All the best Allen
Posts.Title: Intermittent hormone therapy happiness

Posts.Content: I had zero physical symptoms prior to DX. My pc was discovered due to my PDA climbing to 6.4. Following surgery I had no pain and spent one night in hospital. My incontinence was with me for 7 weeks post surgery, and my ED lasted almost 2 years, although I could get an erection with Viagra or Cialis. The only side affect I had was from the anesthetic, it left my brain foggy for almost 2 months. And I find I have slight discomfort from sudden changes in barometric pressure, again due to the anesthetic. I had my surgery at 65. Allen

Posts.Content: Not sure how contamination could take place. Needles only used once, each needle is in aseptic packaging, and I use a surgical glove when changing needles. But I suppose all things are possible,.
Posts.Title: Penile injection method

Posts.Content: Well the hospital pharmacy where I get my prescription filled showed me how to draw with the larger needle, then switch the needle itself to a much thinner one for injection. It allows me to pain free inject on the same side if I choose. You can't feel the needle entering. Just different instructions from different source. After my instruction with pharmacist I had an appointment with my surgeon's nurse who showed me exactly where to insert the needle.

Posts.Content: Hi Ed, yes you have good reason to be concerned. My surgeon sent me to a great oncologist when my PSA reached .17 abot 1 year after surgery. My side affects were zero and after 33 rounds and 15 months later my PSA is 0.0 It had previously climbed to 0.17 a year after surgery. My Gleason was 7; (3+4). Unfortunately I can't offer advice on question #2 Good Luck Allen

Posts.Content: Hi Hammer, I had salvation Radiation 3 years ago and have had no side effects really. The important thing is to have an empty bowel and full bladder when you get on the table. From the time you go in the room, until you leave will be approximately 10-12 minutes. They start by getting you positioned on the table, then they do a mini cat scan to verify your bowel and bladder are as they should be. It is really nothing to sweat over, you can return to work, go shoot pool or whatever. Allen
Posts.Title: Questions on upcoming salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Tom's wife..This may not be as delicate a subject as you think. All of us who have had to deal with pc have been to hell and back in one form or another. The vast majority have had to deal with Incontinence and ED some for a short time, some for many years. Personally it may be your husband is tired of people handling him delicately and would just like to hear straight talk. I think you need to be tactful but you should make him understand he is not the only person going through this and he should peruse this site and read some of the stories. Some are upbeat of guys in the zero club and at the opposite end are guys wondering how long they can expect to live. Obviously you are a loving, supportive wife but please don't give him a wheel chair, get him walking and running. Brave

Posts.Title: Questions about Viagra/Generic Viagra

Posts.Content: Welcome Punta, I used the standard formula of Tri Mix for about a year. During the first 8 months I found myself having to move front .1 to .8 in order to maintain a good erection for 30-45 minutes. I then tried cutting back to .3 and taking 5mg of Cialis a few hours before (My Uro did not recommend this). The results were great. Two months ago I woke up with an erection and was able to maintain it without injection or Cialis. My doctor said it is not uncommon for some men to go years without an erection and suddenly it appears. You could ask your Uro about combining Cialis and Tri Mix. I never did tell my Uro, but don't recommend it. I am now 67, how old are you? B

All unimportant when you're young and healthy, but when you get older and need a major operation, or MRI, Cat Scans, Radiation, it becomes quite important.
